title: Will negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) be completed in 2017?
preds: I doubt anything is going to jappen in the next week.

he Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) leaders who met on the sidelines of the 31st ASEAN Summit in Manila recently have expressed their commitment to resolve differences and conclude the ASEAN+6 country free trade agreement (FTA) by 2018
http://bilaterals.org/?regional-comprehensive-economic
The talks on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) failed to reach its expected "substantial conclusion" this year.

ASEAN communique stalls amid disagreement on South China Sea stance

I am a bit lost how to come up with a justifiably probability on the question (a question which has more brier score downside than upside). Found articles claiming that an agreement could be reached end of this year as well as early 2018. Given that RCEP discussions have been ongoing for some years now, they might conclude soon. Nevertheless, forecasters here seem sure that it will not happen.
Dropping to zero because I read a lot more about counties hopes than I do about progress.

The negotiations are not likely to conclude this year and may move into the first half of 2018.
http://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/current-affairs/280617/rcep-pact-700-officials-from-16-nations-to-meet-in-hyderabad.html
Updating for the passage of time.

The RCEP is often described, inaccurately, as a China-led agreement competing with the TPP for influence in Asia. In fact, the RCEP is largely an initiative led by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). It joins together ASEAN members and the six countries with which ASEAN has existing free trade agreements: Australia, New Zealand, Japan, China, India and Korea.
I've been high, but time is a'wasting, so lowering %.
Given tensions between the Asian countries of late, I can certainly see talks taking place but an agreement being reached before the end of the year seems highly unlikely
Relative Trade information of the Asian area.
India skips China's Silk Road summit, warns of 'unsustainable' debt
If RCEP plans to go ahead without the US, then I would put the chances for completion at 50 percent to take place in 2017.

This one continues to trudge along.  Nobody seems in much of a hurry to push it forward, and reports on the negotiations sound like it's pretty much house-to-house fighting at this point.   In theory it could break open fast; but as Yogi Berra said, or should have, theory and practice are the same in theory, but not in practice.  Coming down again.
Asian Nations Swimming in Debt at Risk From Fed Rate Hikes

The boys are back in town, but probably they have let this languish too long to meet the deadline for this Q.  However, if it is revived a few more times it will probably resolve as a Y; the Chinese are keenly aware that the US flight from economics creates an enormous opening for them.  Stay tuned.
If they reach a "framework," which has been repeated in the news lately... with secondary parts to come later, does that count as an agreement?

As a rule when is comes to trade agreements: they will take longer then anyone thought possible and someone everyone still ends up unhappy. Now with India being difficult at the last negotiating round, that could easily add six months and two negotiation round to the whole process.
not optimistic as the whole world examine the new Trump policy especially related to the globalization , green house ,…

Iman Pambagyo, trade negotiating committee chief for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, said that governments had the political will to conclude the deal despite differences on goods and services, in part to send a message in the face of rising protectionism elsewhere. Only 10 percent of the text has been completed, he said.

Negotiations recently commenced and I believe the is some time in 2017 to possibly reach an agreement.  There might be some motivation to complete the agreement in 2017 in order to remove uncertainty that comes with the Trump administration.

Poor start to the year.
Key Asia trade talks on alternative to TPP end, no major deal struck

Given the US' abandonment of TPP and its belligerency of several countries, the countries will take the next-best step forward for a regional economic deal.
Droping 15 points, not seeing much movement on this. Also moving toward consensus.

As the many countries party to these negotiations get into the meat of the issues, it becomes more clear of the difficulties associated with the negotiation of this agreement or any trade agreement for that matter. I believe that because there is a  global spotlight on this agreement as a result of the US withdrawal from the TPP, there may be increasing pressure on all countries to meet their own countries' expectations or at the very least for the group to strive for a quality vs. speedy agreement. So I'm moving the probability of them reaching consensus down to 5%.

chances increasing after Trump took over
Increased attractiveness of regional pacts give recent political changes.

1.Members of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) will likely focus on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), now that the US has pulled out of the deal, says United Overseas Bank (UOB) Malaysia Bhd.
With the collapse of the TPP, trade departments will be anxious to show results.... This should assist "consensus reaching" for the RCEP.

Too many wildcards in the mix - Trump, China, China's reaction to Trump - plus the usual problems with multilateral negotiations.
They will not want to step out front as a collective. Might be viewed as isolationist by Western nations.

1.  RCEP negotiations were formally launched in November 2012 at the ASEAN Summit in Cambodia. RCEP is viewed as an alternative to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade agreement, which excludes China and India and includes several nations of the Americas.
Persuaded by https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/439662 and consensus. Dropping from 80 to 45.
Such trade deals are part of geopolitics that I watch.
Because I think it is very iffy.  Folks to not appear to be working together for a solution.

The RCEP was China's response to the US-backed TPP. The goal of the prior US efforts was to decrease barriers between the US and many East & Southeast Asian countries, not including China.
Its a longer process which needs a lot of negotiation.
India should play proactive role in promoting open global markets

US withdrawal from TPP may increase the intensity of serious negotiations but that the leads to serious issues and problems that take time to resolve. Not sure it will get done this year with all the other crisis situations arising worldwide.
Malaysia, Thailand and NewZealand pushing for a resolution. Meeting in Japan next month. http://en.vietnamplus.vn/thailand-backs-faster-conclusion-of-rcep-negotiations/106508.vnp
Moving from 20% to 15% to keep ahead of the consensus
No multilateral agreement is easy or quick. There remain significant open issues to be resolved - IP rights for example.

https://www.ft.com/content/eeaa19f0-e1fb-11e6-8405-9e5580d6e5fb
Seems to be moe uncertainty after the US leaves the TPP.

Will the traditional major allies (India, Japan, S.Korea, Australia, New Zealand) of the United States join RCEP?  China will certainly push hard for the agreement, as Chinese ambitions will have to be acted upon with an accelerated time frame as the US withdraws internationally and pursues the America first policy.  I'm not so sure that the traditional allies will be comfortable pivoting toward China within the year, they may need more time to assess the Geopolitical landscape as the Trump administration's policies take effect.  However, China may push the partnership through with a majority of the 10 ASEAN member countries in order to gain clout within SE Asia while the window of opportunity is ripe, with or without Japan, S.Korea, India, Australia, N.Z.

RCEP is a huge trade agreement and these take time and have lots of moving parts and friction points. With the US leaving TPP it would be tempting to think that RCEP will quickly step in the void but there are problems. Will India want to be a part of it? Will other members of ASEAN see RCEP as a blatant Chinese attempt to push their “Belt and Road” strategy? There are also many other smaller trade deals still moving forward in the region and TPP is still being pursued by ASEAN members. The US is leaving the game but it does not mean that RCEP is a sure deal.
Let's not forget that there is a huge gap in the Indian and Chinese expectations from RCEP. I am skeptical of it going through in 2017.

RCEP has toxic provisions similar to the USA TPP inserted by US allies. Until those provisions are removed, which I do think is likely, this agreement won't succeed. 
http://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/1182745/the-rcep-has-become-more-relevant-than-ever
This is China's big chance--well, one of them--to grab influence in the region as the US, led by--well, nobody--slinks off to hide under its bed for a few years.
Improved success due to U.S. trade isolationism and rejection of TPP.
